author: CDC
title: Antibiotic use in rural hospitals as a public health issue
text:
What to know
- Rural communities are complex and have strengths and assets that can help them overcome health challenges, and not all communities have the same health disparities. CDC’s mission extends to all Americans. Where they live should not limit their health outcomes or potential.
A closer look at rural health
[Antibiotic Use in Rural Hospitals](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/antibiotic-use-in-rural-hospitals.html) - Antibiotic stewardship programs improve how hospitals use antibiotics and result in improved patient outcomes. About 1 in 3 antibiotics prescribed in hospitals is not needed or are prescribed incorrectly. [Arthritis in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/arthritis-in-rural-america.html) - Arthritis describes over 100 conditions that affect the joints, tissues around the joint, and other connective tissues. More than 1 in 3 adults in rural areas have arthritis. Community-based physical activity programs in rural areas can help adults manage arthritis pain. [Cancer in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-considerations-for-cancer-in-rural-america.html) - Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States. Compared to urban areas, rural areas have lower rates of new cancer cases, but the cancer death rate is higher.2 [Child Health in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-considerations-for-child-health-in-rural-america.html) - Parents of children with mental, behavioral, and developmental disorders in rural communities often report more hardships than their urban counterparts. Children with these disorders who live in rural areas could benefit from better access to mental and behavioral healthcare programs that support parents and caregivers. [COPD Urban-Rural Differences](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-considerations-for-chronic-obstructive-pulmonary-disease-copd.html) - People living in rural areas face higher risks for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Rural areas have more smoking, less access to programs to help quit smoking, and limited healthcare. Improved access to healthcare can lead to better quality of life and reduced deaths. [COPD Burden](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-strategies-for-copd-burden.html) - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or COPD, is a group of diseases that cause airflow blockage and breathing-related problems. It includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis. People living in rural areas experience higher rates of COPD, COPD-related hospitalizations covered by Medicare, and COPD deaths than urban Americans. [Diabetes Self-Management in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-considerations-for-diabetes-self-management-education-and-support-in-rural-america.html) - 1 in 10 Americans have diabetes. Diabetes self-management education and support (DSMES) helps manage diabetes, but most rural areas don't have DSMES programs. 62% of rural counties in the United States do not have diabetes self-management education and support. [Drug Overdose in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-considerations-for-drug-overdose-in-rural-america.html) - Drug overdoses are the leading cause of injury or death in the U.S. People who live in rural areas are now at greater risk of death from drug overdose than people who live in urban areas. Understanding differences in rural and urban drug overdose deaths can lead to better responses by healthcare professionals. [Health Behaviors in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-considerations-for-health-behaviors-in-rural-america.html) - People living in rural areas in the U.S. are more likely than their urban counterparts to be at higher risk for certain diseases and health conditions. Most chronic diseases can be prevented by eating well, being physically active, avoiding tobacco and excessive drinking, and getting regular health screenings. [Motor Vehicle Safety in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/motor-vehicle-safety-in-rural-america.html) - Deaths from motor vehicle accidents in rural areas are much higher than those in urban areas. The resources on this page help show why this is happening in rural areas and how they can be addressed. [Suicide in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/suicide-in-rural-america-prevention-strategies.html) - People who live in rural areas are at a higher risk for suicide than people who live in urban areas. Suicide rates almost doubled between 2000-2020 in rural areas. [Vaccination in Rural Communities](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-strategies-for-vaccination-in-rural-communities.html) - Many adolescents in rural communities are not getting the recommended vaccines to protect against diseases. It is important to support healthcare professionals in effectively recommending vaccines for adolescents and addressing parents’ concerns. [Zoonotic Diseases in Rural America](/rural-health/php/public-health-strategy/public-health-strategies-for-zoonotic-diseases-in-rural-america.html) - Zoonotic diseases are infections that spread between animals and people. People can become infected with these diseases by interacting with animals. People in rural areas are often in contact with more animals than people in urban areas. The resources below can help people understand and prevent infection from zoonotic diseases. [Public Health Infrastructure Center](/infrastructure/index.html)

author: archyde
title: Woman Dies from Exhaustion During New Year's Fireworks in Depok
text:
New Year’s Eve Celebrations turn Tragic in Depok A somber note marked the beginning of 2025 as tragedy struck a New Year’s Eve celebration in Depok. Details surrounding the incident are still emerging,but the event has cast a pall over the start of the new year for the community. Authorities have commenced an investigation too determine the cause of the tragedy and ensure appropriate measures are taken to prevent similar incidents in the future. A New Year’s Eve celebration turned into a scene of mourning as a young person, identified only as IR, tragically lost their life during the festivities.Though the official cause of death is still under investigation, early reports suggest that IR may have succumbed to the overwhelming crowds and the resulting strain on their body.
Witnesses described a night of intense overcrowding, leading to speculation that IR may have experienced exhaustion and difficulty breathing in the chaotic environment.
“While the exact cause of death is yet to be persistent,” officials stated, emphasizing the ongoing investigation.
## Archyde Interviews: Unraveling the Tragedy in Depok
**[Start of Interview]**
**Host**: Welcome back to Archyde News. Today, we are joined by [Alex Reed Name], a sociologist studying social behavior during public events. Earlier this week, a tragic incident occurred in Depok, Indonesia, where a woman identified as IR passed away during New Year’s Eve celebrations near a shopping mall. We’re here to discuss the incident and its context with our Alex Reed.
[Alex Reed Name], thank you for joining us. To our viewers, please remember that the cause of IR’s death is still under investigation.
**Alex Reed**: thank you for having me.It’s a deeply unfortunate incident that casts a shadow over what should have been a time of celebration.
**Host**: Absolutely. Could you provide some context about the potential factors that could contribute to such an incident during a large public gathering like New Year’s Eve?
**Alex Reed**: Certainly.Large crowds, particularly during festive occasions, present unique challenges. The dense population, amplified emotions, and potential exhaustion can create a stressful environment.
Medical emergencies can occur in any setting, but the added pressure of a crowded and celebratory atmosphere can make it harder for individuals to recognize warning signs in themselves or others. Additionally, access to immediate medical assistance might be delayed in such situations.
**Host**: The incident happened outside a shopping mall during a fireworks display. Do you think thes factors played a role?
**Alex Reed**: It’s possible. Fireworks displays are certainly attention-grabbing, and the excitement they generate can lead to heightened sensory stimulation. While this doesn’t inherently cause medical emergencies, it could potentially exacerbate underlying health conditions in some individuals or contribute to a sense of disorientation or overwhelm, especially in a crowded environment.
**Host**: What are some recommendations for individuals attending large public events to ensure their safety and well-being?
**Alex Reed**: Awareness is key. Pay attention to your body and surroundings. If you feel overwhelmed, take a break from the crowd, find a quieter space, and stay hydrated. Look out for each other; be attentive to the well-being of those around you, especially vulnerable individuals. And remember, if you or someone near you needs medical attention, don’t hesitate to seek help immediately.
**Host**: Thank you for sharing those valuable insights, [Alex Reed Name].
**[End of Interview]** Tragedy Strikes New Year’s Eve Celebration A New Year’s Eve celebration turned into a scene of mourning as a young person, identified only as IR, tragically lost their life during the festivities.Though the official cause of death is still under investigation, early reports suggest that IR may have succumbed to the overwhelming crowds and the resulting strain on their body.
Witnesses described a night of intense overcrowding, leading to speculation that IR may have experienced exhaustion and difficulty breathing in the chaotic environment.
“While the exact cause of death is yet to be persistent,” officials stated, emphasizing the ongoing investigation.

author: Lance
title: Manchester City surpreende Chelsea e vence na Champions Feminina
text:
Manchester City surpreende Chelsea e vence na Champions Feminina
Equipes vão se enfrentar novamente na próxima semana pelo torneio continental
O Manchester City venceu o Chelsea por 2 a 0 pelo jogo de ida das quartas de final da Champions League Feminina, nesta quarta-feira (19). Com o resultado, os Cityzens levam uma vantagem de dois gols para o jogo de volta e se aproximam de uma vaga na semifinal da competição.
➡️ Tudo sobre os maiores times e as grandes estrelas do futebol no mundo afora agora no WhatsApp. Siga o nosso canal Lance! Futebol Internacional
Como foi o jogo?
A primeira etapa foi inteiramente dominada pelas mandantes. O Manchester City criou várias oportunidades de gol, ficando a um detalhe de abrir o placar. Por outro lado, o Chelsea não conseguiu sair da pressão do City e, por consequência, acabou sendo muito inofensivo no ataque. A atacante Fowler foi o destaque dos primeiros 45 minutos.
O segundo tempo começou como terminou o primeiro: com City pressionando muito. O zero saiu do placar aos 60 minutos, com Miedema. A ponta-esquerda, que entrou no lugar da Murphy no início da segunda etapa, aproveitou o rebote da goleira, após uma cabeçada perigosa no meio da área, e mandou para o fundo da rede.
Após o gol, o Manchester seguiu controlando o jogo. No entanto, as visitantes foram igualando as forças com o passar do tempo. Nos últimos 10 minutos, a pressão mudou de lado e a equipe azul de Londres levou perigo ao gol adversário. Mesmo assim, a pressão das visitantes não surtiu efeito, e o City no contra-ataque deu números finais a partida, com Miedema novamente.
O que vem por aí?
As equipes voltam a se enfrentar no próximo domingo (23), às 11h30 (de Brasília), no Etihad Stadium, em Manchester. A partida é válida pelo Campeonato Inglês Feminino.
